inputFields.label: ANITA SCIPIO
HILTON V. SCIPIO

description: Title page for 'Hip-Hop Time Capsule: Document Your Personal Journey' with subtitle and author attribution fields for two authors
A blank page with only the page number '2' centered at the bottom

Thank you page featuring a quote 'Your Support Is Everything!' with decorative musical notes, followed by 'Thank you!' and signed by 'Anita Scipio and DJ SCIPIO'. The page includes decorative silhouettes at the bottom showing a breakdancer, cassette tape, and dancer figure.
Copyright page containing all rights reserved notice and copyright symbol with '2024 TEAM SCIPIO' at the bottom. Page number 4 appears at the bottom center.

Table of Contents page listing 16 chapters with page numbers, including sections on Title Page, Autograph Page, Copyright Page, Foreward, Kool Moe Dee Hats, Introduction, dedications, personal journey questions, hip-hop quotes, trivia questions, and journey stories from DJ SCIPIO and Anita Scipio

Table of Contents page showing chapters 17-30 with page numbers ranging from 220-284. Includes topics about Angela Yee, The Breakfast Club, DJ SCIPIO sections, author bios for Hilton and Anita Scipio, celebrity photos, and closing chapters. Contains a note at bottom about automatic numbering system for the first three pages.

Foreword page introducing the Hip-Hop Time Capsule book, written about co-authors Anita Scipio and DJ SCIPIO (Hilton V. Scipio). The text describes Hip-Hop as a living cultural testament and explains the authors' extensive experience in the Hip-Hop industry - DJ SCIPIO with over 45 years in the Carolinas and Anita Scipio with nearly two decades at iHeartMedia.

This page contains an introduction and historical note about Hip-Hop, signed by Kool Moe Dee. It describes personal experiences and introduces a 'Hip-Hop Time Capsule' concept. The bottom section features a note from the authors about the historic 1981 battle between Kool Moe Dee and Busy Bee Starski at Harlem World, with three QR codes linking to recordings of this historic battle.

A page titled 'Kool Moe Dee: Hats' featuring two photographs of the artist wearing sunglasses and hats, followed by biographical text describing Kool Moe Dee as a pioneering rapper and Hip-Hop artist. The text explains his role in Treacherous Three, his musical contributions, and his passion for hats. The page mentions his agreement to write a foreword with the condition that hats' significance in Hip-Hop be emphasized.

This page discusses the cultural significance of hats in hip-hop, featuring a quote from Kool Moe Dee explaining how hats became symbols of empowerment and identity, representing a metaphorical African crown. The page concludes with a summary about how hip-hop fashion choices had lasting impact on broader fashion culture.

Conclusion page of a section about hats in early Hip-Hop, signed by Anita, followed by a fun fact quiz matching Hip-Hop artists to their iconic headwear from the Hip-Hop Time Capsule cover. Lists The Notorious B.I.G. (crown), RUN-DMC (black Fedora), Queen Latifah (yellow-gold Kufi-style crown hat), LL Cool J (red Kangol), and Kool Moe Dee (black leather flat top Kufi).

Introduction page with decorative musical notes header. The page introduces the book 'Hip-Hop Time Capsule' and explains the author Anita Scipio's background as an 18-year iHeartMedia receptionist and lifelong Hip-Hop fan since 1978. It describes her inspiration from attending the Hip-Hop 50 Live Concert at Yankee Stadium on August 12, 2023, which led to creating this book to help people document their personal Hip-Hop journeys and memories.

Foreword or introduction page explaining the author's motivation for creating 'Hip-Hop Time Capsule: Document Your Personal Journey.' The author discusses their collaboration with co-author DJ SCIPIO, acknowledges their own limitations as a fan rather than expert, and explains how they learned about Hip-Hop's origins from pioneers like DJ Hollywood, Grandmaster Flowers, Disco King Mario, and Cool Herc. The page mentions the book contains 100 thought-provoking questions and emphasizes its uniqueness in the market.

This is a foreword or introduction page (page 14) where the author discusses the challenging process of writing a book about Hip-Hop's 50-year history. The author mentions including 50 quotes, 50 trivia questions, and 235 QR codes throughout the book. They also acknowledge working with their brother Hilton (DJ SCIPIO) and discuss the various setbacks faced during the book's creation.

Page explaining the QR code feature in the book, describing how selected codes link to hip-hop songs to create an interactive experience. Discusses the decision to use original versions of songs and link to official platforms like YouTube to support artists while avoiding copyright issues. The page emphasizes making the book family-friendly and creating an interactive journey through hip-hop history.

Introduction page explaining copyright and QR code linking policies for Hip-Hop content, followed by a section header introducing a Hip-Hop Time Capsule feature for documenting personal journey. Includes content warning about audience suitability and describes the evolution of the journal project from original plan to include personal experiences.

Content page explaining why the book was split into two volumes. The author describes how the project grew beyond its original format and became too large for a single volume. Includes a heading 'Why This book Became Two Volumes' in purple text. The page discusses the division of content between volumes and acknowledges a colleague named Thea Mitchem from iHeartMedia.

Announcement page for upcoming book 'this time in color' and Hip-Hop Time Capsule app. Features two QR codes - one linking to Brian Moore's Portfolio (bmoore4452.github.io) and one for Instagram (@BMOORE4452). Includes promotional text about the new book having a foreword by a Hip-Hop legend and featuring artists/legends on a deeper personal level. Also announces an app created by nephew Brian Moore coming to Apple, Android and Web.

A 'Sneak Peek' page showing two framed photographs at the top - one featuring Kool Moe Dee and LL Cool J, another featuring 50 Cent. Below is a list of famous hip-hop artists and celebrities mentioned in the book, including Kool Moe Dee, LL Cool J, Snoop Dogg, DMX, Will Smith, Salt-N-Pepa, Mary J Blige, Fat Joe, Ice Tea, Rick Ross, Ice Cube, 50 Cent, Young MA, 2 Chainz, Da Baby, Jezzy, Run-DMC, French Montana, Redman, Wiz Khalifa, Big Sean, Nelly, TI, Sean Paul, Treach, Moneybagg Yo, and many more.

A tribute page dedicated to DaBaby, featuring two photos at the top - one black and white photo on the left and one color photo with multiple people on the right. The page contains a heartfelt story about a retired person's encounter with DaBaby on October 1st, describing how the artist went out of his way to connect after missing them at The Breakfast Club. The text includes gratitude messages to Sherri, Garrett, and the team, signed by 'Mama'. The page includes the 'stay TUNED' logo at the bottom and is numbered page 20.

A dedication page titled 'ANITA'S DEDICATION' featuring two photographs showing family members together. The page contains a heartfelt dedication message to the author's daughter Arlene Yvette Scipio and granddaughter Gayla Renee Robinson, expressing love, gratitude, and blessings. The message is signed 'Love, Mom & Grandma' with decorative heart graphics.

A dedication page titled 'HILTON'S DEDICATION' featuring two photographs at the top - one showing a person in a yellow dress holding a Broadway playbill, and another showing a young girl in pink. Below is a heartfelt dedication message from Dad/Papa Scipio to his daughter Cheri Scipio-White, granddaughters Kadence L. White and Chloe N. White, and late son Hilton Fuquan Scipio (RIP). The dedication discusses the book's purpose to share Hip-Hop journey memories and inspire family. The page is decorated with purple floral graphics at the bottom corners and includes a dove symbol.

inputFields.label: 1. When did you first discover Hip-Hop music?
2. Do you remember where you were?
inputFields.example_answer: The first time I discovered Hip-Hop, I was in school. I traded a cassette tape with one of my classmates.

description: Interactive questionnaire page with two questions about discovering Hip-Hop music. Each question has a numbered speech bubble (1 and 2 in magenta circles) with example answers provided. Questions ask about when and where the reader first discovered Hip-Hop. Page is attributed to @DJ SCIPIO at the bottom.

Page 94 showing questions 3 and 4 of an interview with DJ Scipio. Question 3 asks about the first song that caught their attention, with the answer being 'Apache' by The Incredible Bongo Band (includes a QR code). Question 4 asks about emotions felt hearing Hip-Hop for the first time, with the answer describing it as a soulful experience. The page features numbered circular badges (3 and 4) and response bubbles in a conversational format.

Page 95 contains two Q&A sections. Question 5 asks about the hottest/illest MCs, with the answer listing Kool Moe Dee, Melle Mel, GrandMaster Caz, Nas, Jay Z, and Jada Kiss. Two QR codes are displayed linking to songs by Nas and Jay-Z. Question 6 asks if Hip-Hop inspired the person to become a DJ/rapper/dancer, with the answer explaining they were already a DJ playing Soul, Disco, and Funk, but the cutting and scratching style of GrandMaster Flash and GrandWizard Theodore inspired them to become a Hip-Hop DJ.

Interview-style Q&A page featuring questions 7 and 8 about Hip-Hop's role in the author's social circles and inspirational songs. Question 7 discusses teaming up with DJ Jazzy G and practicing mixing skills. Question 8 lists three songs that provided confidence: 'The Message' by GrandMaster Flash and the Furious Five, 'Self Destruction' by KRS-1, and 'Yes We Can Can' by The Treacherous Three. Includes a QR code and attribution to @DJ SCIPIO.

Page containing questions 9 and 10 about hip-hop history. Question 9 asks about top five hottest jams/concerts with an answer about venues in the Boogie Down Bronx. Question 10 asks about top DJs who impacted Hip-Hop, listing numerous influential DJs including Disco King Mario, DJ Kool Herc, Grandmaster Flash, and others, with special mention of Frankie Crocker's role. The page includes three QR codes at the bottom linking to '52 Beats' by Kid Capri, DJ Kayslay content, and 'Old School Flava' by DJ Hollywood.

Q&A page with two questions and answers. Question 11 asks about favorite crew members to party with, answered with names like Greg Simpkins (G Money), Dave Brown (Kool Dave), Dwayne Murray Greene (Dee Money), Billy Robinson, and Curvas Moore (Q). Question 12 asks about top three old-school dances, with answer listing The Hustle, The Freak Dance, and The Bump from back in the day, and The Electric Slide for today.

Q&A page featuring questions 13 and 14 about hip-hop clubs and party songs. Question 13 asks about top five hip-hop clubs, with answer listing Disco Fever, T-Connection, The Stardust Ballroom, Club 371, and The Sparkle in the Bronx. Question 14 asks about top party songs that 'rocked the house', with answer listing 'Wild Wild West' by Kool Moe Dee, 'Planet Rock' by Afrika Bambaataa and Soulsonic Force, 'It Takes Two' by Rob Base & DJ E-Z Rock, 'Set It Off' by Strafe, and 'Jam On It' by Newcleus. Three QR codes are displayed at the bottom for 'Wild Wild West', 'Planet Rock', and 'Jam On It'. Page is credited to @DJ SCIPIO and numbered 99.

Page 100 containing questions 15 and 16 about hip-hop music. Question 15 asks about the first song the reader could fully recite, with an answer about 'The Message' by Grandmaster Flash and a QR code. Question 16 asks about the top five 'illiest' male artists or groups from the reader's era, with an answer listing The Treacherous Three, The L Brothers, The Cold Crush Brothers, Grandmaster Flash and The Furious Five, and Crash Crew. Two QR codes are included linking to songs 'White Lines' and 'High Power Rap'.

Q&A page featuring questions 17 and 18. Question 17 asks about a concert/event regretted missing, with a detailed answer about the historic 1981 Busy Bee Starsky vs Kool Moe Dee MC battle at Harlem World. Three QR codes are shown linking to related videos. Question 18 asks about old school lines still recited, with a brief response stating inability to name specific lines or verses.

Q&A page containing questions 19 and 20 about DJ Scipio's favorite songs. Question 19 asks about favorite club songs, listing 11 tracks including 'Apache' by The Incredible Bongo Band and others. Question 20 asks about top five favorite Break Dance tracks for B-Boys, listing 5 songs including 'The Mexican' by Babe Ruth and 'Give It Up Turn It Loose' by James Brown. Page number 102 appears at bottom.

Q&A page featuring questions 21 and 22. Question 21 asks about DJ equipment ownership, with answer describing Technic Turntables, Gemini Mixer, and Kenwood Amp. Question 22 asks about club violence, with answer describing an incident at The Valley in The Bronx with DJ Jazzy G and DJ Whiz Kid.

inputFields.response: Yes, I have been affected by the loss of a Hip-Hop artist.

inputFields.label: If so, how were you specifically affected?
inputFields.response: I was saddened by the loss of my friend, DJ Whiz Kid. Also, DJ Silverback and DJ Robert Randolph of Orangeburg, SC.

inputFields.label: 31. What record pool, if any, did you belong to?

inputFields.label: 32. When you were on your way to a club; looking clean (or as we used to say) looking fresh, what were your favorite colognes, perfumes, or body oils to wear?

inputFields.label: 33. Fashion is an integral part of Hip-Hop. Back in your day, what was your favorite Hip-Hop drip (or as we used to say) gear?

inputFields.label: 34. What was your sneaker or shoe game like? And now?

inputFields.label: 41. Have you ever met or worked with any of your favorite artists or legends in Hip-Hop?
inputFields.response: Yes, I have met and worked with some of my favorite artists. Kool Moe Dee and I were sixth grade classmates. We both attended P.S. 129 in Harlem. I also met Queen Latifah, Prodigy of Mobb Deep, Run-DMC and Grandmaster Jay, Raekwon, T.I., Lil' Jon, Rasheeda, Scrappy, Scarface, Pastor Troy, Master P and many more.

inputFields.label: 43. What were your thoughts on the infamous East Coast vs. West Coast War? Did you choose a side?

inputFields.response: If I had fifteen minutes with my favorite Hip-Hop Legend, it would be Mary J. Blige. I would commend her on all of her accomplishments and ask her, "What are your plans for the evening?" LOL!

inputFields.label: If you could have a rap battle with any of your favorite artists, who would you choose?
inputFields.example_answer: I would have a rap battle with Jay Z.

inputFields.label: 63. Have there been any songs or specific artists that aided you in finding your voice and shaping your identity? If so, which ones?
inputFields.responseText: Yes. The particular artists that helped me find my voice and my own identity was the group Public Enemy.

inputFields.label: 64. How do you feel about the storytelling aspect of Hip-Hop? Have you ever written your own stories?
inputFields.responseText: The storytelling aspect of Hip-Hop was a great contribution. No, I have not written my story yet, but it may be coming soon.

description: Page 124 containing questions 63 and 64 about hip-hop influences and storytelling, with handwritten-style responses provided. Question 63 discusses Public Enemy's influence, and question 64 discusses storytelling in hip-hop with a note about potentially writing a story in the future. Authored by DJ Scipio.

inputFields.label: 65. Do you remember a time when Hip-Hop brought the people in your community together?
inputFields.prefilledAnswer: Yes, when someone in the community passed away, we would celebrate their life with a block party. We would get together, have some food and play their favorite songs.

inputFields.label: 66. Did Hip-Hop make you more active in your community? If so, what changes did you make and how did you improve things for the better?
inputFields.prefilledAnswer: Yes, as a DJ, I contributed to the community by organizing fundraisers and 'Back-to-School' drives. Many adults and children needed financial help and it made a difference for them.

description: Page 125 of a Hip-Hop questionnaire featuring questions 65 and 66 about community engagement through Hip-Hop, with pre-filled responses from DJ Scipio. inputFields.label: 74. What artist or group, if any, do you believe is over-hyped or has negatively impacted the music? If so, who and how?

inputFields.label: 25. Have you ever had the opportunity to do something kind or important for your favorite artist?
inputFields.responseText: Yes, DMX came to Power 105.1 for an interview with The Breakfast Club. Because DMX would occasionally have asthma attacks, and they wanted to be prepared just in case, I received a request to find an EpiPen for him and after making several phone calls, finally, my awesome co-worker, Jill Shelhorse, came through for me! She bought one upstairs and I was so grateful. I was beaming with pride and so honored that I got a chance to do something for the legendary DMX. Thank God, he didn't need it that day but regardless, we had his back!

inputFields.label: Have you ever met or worked with any of your favorite artists or legends in Hip-Hop?
inputFields.prefilledAnswer:
I have been very fortunate to have met many of my favorite Hip-Hop legends. Working at iHeartMedia, the parent company of Power 105.1, was an absolute dream job. It doesn't get any better than working with The Breakfast Club and the best of the best DJs/On-Air Personalities in the game. However, I would like to single out ***Lisa Glasberg, aka Lisa G. She was my co-worker at iHeartMedia, and she is a good friend of mine. She is one of the kindest and most generous people I know. She is also a Hip-Hop legend. Here is a little research on Lisa G.

She was a prominent radio personality and co-host on Hot 97's morning show with Ed Lover and Dr. Dre in the 1990s. It was one of the first Hip-Hop Morning Shows on an all Hip-Hop format. She played an essential role in the early days of mainstream Hip-Hop radio, helping to bring rap music and culture to a wider audience. This show helped shape Hip-Hop radio, blending humor, music, and interviews with some of the biggest rap stars of the time. Many listeners assumed she was black because her voice and style fit seamlessly with the culture. She was well respected for her work and authenticity. Her time on Hot 97, solidified her place in Hip-Hop history. ***Love you Lisa G. Proud to know you! Anita

Question 93 asks who won and which song led to that conclusion, with the answer declaring Kendrick Lamar's 'Not Like Us' as the winner. Each answer includes a QR code linking to the respective songs mentioned.

inputFields.label: Response to question 94: Did the opinion of those in your inner-circle match yours, or were there drastic differences?
Response to question 95: Do rivalries benefit or negatively impact Hip-Hop and the overall culture?
inputFields.content: In most cases, they're beneficial; however, with the Drake and Kendrick beef, I felt as though they each were trying to end the other's career, and I wasn't so sure about this one. The hatred displayed on both sides was palpable, and it was low-down and dirty, but I might add... very entertaining! Now, there is even a lawsuit that has come from this beef. I never thought that would happen in Hip-Hop but here we are... Yikes!

description: Interactive page with two questions (94 and 95) about hip-hop culture, with response bubbles containing answers. Question 94 is about inner-circle opinions, and question 95 discusses rivalries in Hip-Hop, specifically mentioning the Drake and Kendrick beef.

Two Q&A entries (questions 96 and 97) discussing iconic hip-hop beefs and breaking news about admired artists. Question 96 lists famous rap rivalries like Kool Moe Dee vs Busy B, Jay-Z vs Nas, Drake vs Kendrick Lamar, etc. Question 97 discusses the author's changed perception of Diddy after controversial hotel video footage.

Page 210 contains questions 98 and 99 about Hip-Hop. Question 98 asks which artists represent the best of old-school and new-school Hip-Hop, with an answer listing artists like Snoop Dogg, LL Cool J, 50 Cent, and others. Five QR codes are displayed linking to songs: 'Paradise' by Fabolous, 'Forgive Me' by Maino, 'Paradise' by Fat Joe/Anitta/DJ Khaled, 'I Might Forgive...But I Don't Forgive' by Jeezy, and 'Hot in Herre' by Nelly. Question 99 asks about the reader's role as a Hip-Hop fan and how it contributes to the culture, with an answer about attending concerts, buying CDs, and showing love to artists.

Question 100 asks 'And finally, when did you realize that you ARE Hip-Hop?' The answer describes attending The Hip-Hop 50 Live at Yankee Stadium on August 11, 2023, where the author witnessed the unity, joy, and power of Hip-Hop culture through tens of thousands of diverse attendees celebrating together for nine hours.

A personal narrative about attending a hip-hop concert with family members across multiple generations. The author describes the shared joy of music, the emotional connection to hip-hop as a genre, and concludes with the realization 'I AM HIP-HOP!' The page is numbered 212 and credited to @ANITA.

Photo collage page showing the Hip-Hop 50 Live Concert at Yankee Stadium with four images: two showing stage and crowd views from different angles, and two showing silhouettes of attendees (identified as Daughter Arlene and Niece Denise in one, and Cool Kev and Melvin in another). Chapter or section title page featuring 'HIP-HOP TIME CAPSULE' at the top with subtitle 'Document Your Personal Journey'. Page number 215 appears at the bottom.

A tribute page dedicated to Misael A. Nunez, featuring a photo of two people in front of an iHeartMedia logo, followed by a heartfelt message from 'Mama' and DJ Scipio expressing gratitude for Misael's support, belief, and dedication to their project. The page is numbered 216.

Dedication page with two sections: 'My Dear Hubby' - a heartfelt thank you to Rodney for his love and support during the creation of this journal/book; and 'My Blessed Family' - expressing gratitude to family members including special mentions of sister Debbie, brother-in-law Isaac Daniels (Foxx), Ray, goddaughter Paula Hampton, and the Scipio family members in the States and England.

A dedication or acknowledgment page addressed to Thea Mitchem, iHeartMedia's E.V.P. of Programming for the Northeast Division and Program Director of Power 105.1 NYC. The page contains a heartfelt thank you message from Anita expressing gratitude for support, kindness, career opportunities, a retirement party, and assistance with a book. The page includes decorative elements at the top and is signed 'Love always, Anita' at the bottom.

An acknowledgments/dedication page titled 'SPECIAL THANKS TO:' featuring a heartfelt message thanking the author's nieces, nephew, best friend, brother, and son from Egypt. The page includes six photographs arranged in two rows showing the author with various family members and friends mentioned in the text. The word 'love' appears as decorative text in the middle of the page with arrow embellishments.

Acknowledgment page expressing gratitude to iHeartMedia executives and radio stations. Lists key personnel including Thea Mitchem (E.V.P. of Programming), Bernie Weiss (Division President), Steve Delusant (President of New York), and Tom Poleman (Chief Programming Officer). Lists several radio stations including Power 105.1 FM, Elvis Duran and The Morning Show, Q104 FM Classic Rock, WLTW Lite FM, WKTU-FM 103.5, 710 WOR, and Premiere Radio. Contains a personal message of thanks from Anita for memories and friendships.

A tribute page featuring two photographs and text about Angela Yee and Dan Greene. The page includes images of Miss Anita with both individuals, along with congratulatory messages expressing appreciation for their kindness and professional relationship. The page shows their connection to 'Way Up with Angela Yee' show and includes warm personal sentiments.

A page titled 'My Recent Visit To: THE BREAKFAST CLUB' containing text about the author's visit to iHeartMedia's New York offices, followed by a section titled 'My Beloved Breakfast Club Family' with a group photograph of the Breakfast Club team in their studio.

A page featuring three photographs from what appears to be a radio station visit. The top photo shows Charlamagne Tha God and DJ Envy with a guest labeled 'Queen Mama' in the center, all posed in front of a blue branded backdrop. Two additional photos below show closer shots of DJ Envy with Queen Mama, and Queen Mama sitting in an ornate gold and white throne-style chair. The page includes a note about the author's book 'In Hip-Hop Time Capsule: The Next Chapter' and mentions detailed stories about the Breakfast Club/Power 105.1 family. Page number 223 appears at the bottom.

This is an acknowledgment or dedication page addressed to DJ Envy and Charlamagne Tha God. The author expresses gratitude for their support and shares a personal story about receiving the advice 'Be Fearless' from DJ Envy, which impacted an artist named Mark Borino. The author also mentions how Charlamagne's book 'Get Honest Or Die Lying: Why Small Talk Sucks' influenced them to be bolder and more open. The page is signed 'Love, Mama' and is numbered 224, referencing 'Hip-Hop Time Capsule: The Next Chapter'.

A dedication/tribute page featuring messages to three people: Jess Hilarious, Loren LoRosa, and Morgan. The page includes a photo of two smiling women (one in yellow) and decorative balloon graphics at the top. Each section contains congratulatory messages and personal appreciations from what appears to be members of The Breakfast Club team.

A gratitude page featuring three photographs of the author with colleagues in the entertainment industry. The page shows Taylor Hayes ('Little One') from 'Ride or Die Daughter', DJ STACiE SPiNS, and Sym Symma. The title expresses thanks to 'Hip-Hop Children' and other Celebrity Co-Workers.

A photo collage page showing four photographs with captions. Top left shows two people dining with caption 'My "Ride or Die son" David'. Top right shows three people together captioned 'My dear sweet "daughters" Kaitlyn and Maria'. Bottom left shows two people with caption 'My Dear "Son" EmEz'. Bottom right shows two people at an event with caption 'My Dear "Daughter" Nyla Symone'. Page number 227 appears at bottom.

A photo collage page showing four photographs of a woman in colorful attire with different people she refers to as her 'sons'. The top left shows her with Nick, top right with Brandon and Eddie F., bottom left with Radio Big Mac (labeled 'Heeey Bay-Bae!' #YERRRP!!!), and bottom right with DJ REDDE. All photos appear to be taken in similar studio or media settings. Page number 228 appears at the bottom.

A photo collage page showing four images of the author with different people who are dear to her. The photos show her with Ty Brazzell (labeled as 'son'), Maurice Mitchell aka Moe (labeled as 'son'), DJ Suss One (labeled as friend), and Sydney Brown (labeled as 'daughter'). Each photo has a caption identifying the person. This appears to be page 229 of the book.

A photo collage page showing four images with captions. The top two images show the author with two different people labeled as 'My Dear Son AJ' and 'My Dear Son Eddie F.' The bottom two images show the author at iHeartMedia, holding a book titled 'The Lost Letters', with captions 'Back Home At iHeartMedia' and 'I love iHeartMedia'. Page number 230 appears at the bottom.

A page containing two heartfelt testimonials. The first is from 'Taylor, aka Little One' describing a loving relationship with devoted memories of finding each other before shifts and sharing hugs. The second is from 'DJ STACIE SPINS AKA Daughterspins' describing their oldest child as a wild, unpredictable person who enjoys intellectual conversations over Chipotle.

A page containing three heartfelt testimonials from 'Mama' about her colleagues: Daughterspins (a DJ), Sym Symma (described as assertive, courageous, and spiritual), and David (who was recently promoted to oversee Promotions at iHeartMedia New York's WWPR/WAXQ/WOR). Each testimonial ends with expressions of love and includes purple-colored emphasized text.

A page containing personal testimonials and tributes. At the top is a message from 'David My Son' expressing love and pride. Below is a photo of a smiling man in a red polo shirt and glasses, with a QR code to the left linking to InsiderRadio.com. The page includes two testimonials: one from 'Maria' about her daughter Maria being a wonderful young lady and their teamwork on prize contests, and another from 'Kaitlyn' about meeting her 'daughter' sweetheart at iHeart after the pandemic and their work together in the promotions and prize department, referring to themselves as 'the Three Musketeers.'

Page 234 contains testimonials or messages about three people: Kaitlyn, EmEz, and Nyla Symone. Each entry appears to be written by 'Mama' describing their relationships and achievements. The text includes personal messages in purple text expressing love and encouragement. The content discusses their professional growth in what appears to be the entertainment industry, mentioning iHeart, concerts, shows, and events.

Acknowledgments page containing heartfelt thank-you messages to various people including Nyla (referred to as 'Mama'), Eddie F (Executive Producer), Marchelle, Miss Anita, Brandon, and Nick. The author expresses gratitude for their support, friendship, and memorable moments shared at a reception/front desk workplace.

Page 236 contains testimonials from mentors about their mentees. Features three stories: one about Nick who progressed from intern to department head, another about Radio Big Mac (Corey) who became successful and appears on Wild N' Out with Nick Cannon, and a third about Maurice Mitchell (Moe Mitchell) who dreamed of becoming a comedian. Each testimonial is signed by the mentor and expresses pride in the mentee's achievements.

A heartfelt page containing two personal messages. The first is from a mother ('Mama') expressing pride in her son who became a comedian and is now part of The Bert Show cast on Q99.7 in Atlanta. The second is from 'Ty' addressing 'Son', reflecting on memories at Reception, officiating his marriage to Amanda, and their 10-year journey with their son Rahmie. Both messages end with loving statements signed 'Mama'. The page number 237 appears at the bottom.

Page 238 contains three acknowledgment sections from Miss Anita expressing gratitude to DJ Redde (her 'son'), DJ Prostyle, and Angie Martinez ('The Voice of New York'). Each section describes personal memories and appreciation for their relationships and professional contributions.

Page 239 contains three tribute sections with personal messages about colleagues/friends: one about Angie (mentioning Niko and family), one about Honey German (described as strong and determined, with green hair), and one about DJ Clue (describing his role in Hip-Hop history and mentioning his daughter Bryana). Each section ends with a personal message in purple text signed by Anita.

Page 240 contains testimonials and messages from Anita about various DJs (DJ Scenario, DJ Whutever, DJ Norie, and DJ Will). Each entry describes personal memories and includes well-wishes signed 'Love, Anita' or 'Love, Mama'. The text includes purple-colored names and closing messages.

Acknowledgments page containing three personal messages from the author Anita to different people: DJ Will (thanking for support and food), Eli (referred to as 'son', thanking for love and support for her book), and DJ Suss One (thanking for friendship, humor, and helping with book promotion including appearance on Sherri Shepard show). Page number 241 appears at bottom.

A page containing farewell messages from coworkers (DJ Self, Sydney, AJ, and Art) expressing gratitude and love, followed by an acknowledgment section titled 'And last but not least...' that mentions Gabe P and his platform On The Radar Radio. The messages are written in a personal, affectionate tone with quotes highlighted in blue/purple text.

A page containing a response to question 58 about challenges faced in choosing a career in Rap or Hip-Hop. The author, who signs as 'Anita aka Miss Anita aka Mama', discusses the enormous challenges in the Hip-Hop industry, including the importance of attitude, commitment, dedication, hard work, and networking. The page includes acknowledgments of Prince Dre from The O and other Hip-Hop voices, with a disclaimer about potentially forgetting to mention someone by name.

inputFields.label: ANITA AKA 'MAMA' SHOUT-OUTS

description: A Hip-Hop Time Capsule page with vibrant purple and pink design featuring a section for documenting personal shout-outs to Anita aka 'Mama'. The page has a star-burst shaped pink text area in the center with torn paper effect borders.

Acknowledgments page featuring two shout-outs. The first thanks Banker.ock (@dhamarseno) for illustration work and includes a QR code. The second acknowledges Ash Cash Exantus, author of 'BOOK RICH: How to Create a Fortune as a Self-Published Author', describing how his interview on The Breakfast Club and subsequent work provided guidance during the book writing process. Includes a QR code linking to 'Earn Your Leisure'.

A 'Shout-Out' page featuring tributes to two Hip-Hop pioneers: Ralph McDaniels, creator of Video Music Box, and Van Silk, the first Hip-Hop promoter. The page includes QR codes for VIDEOMUSICBOX and RAPMANIA_VANSILK, biographical information about their contributions to Hip-Hop culture, and acknowledgments of their support.

A 'Next Level Shout-Outs' acknowledgments page listing names of supporters, donors, or contributors. The page is decorated with two gold heart emojis at the top and features a centered title with decorative divider. Names are arranged in two columns, with some entries including 'Family' or multiple names, suggesting personal dedications or sponsor acknowledgments. Page number 247 appears at the bottom.

A 'Next Level Shout-Outs' acknowledgments page featuring two columns of names of people being thanked. The page is decorated with gold hearts at the top corners and a pink decorative divider. At the bottom is a special message in blue text: 'SHOUT-OUT TO MY POWER 105.1 MUSIC DAY FAMILY! I MISS YOU AND LOVE YOU ALWAYS! -ANITA'. The page contains approximately 60 names arranged in two columns.

A business shout-outs page featuring testimonials for local businesses including Doc's Cake Shop, Custom Candle Co., Lex Restaurant, and Coleman Chauffeur Service. Each testimonial is accompanied by QR codes and business logos. The page header indicates these are not sponsored endorsements, signed by Anita.

A tribute page titled 'Shout-Out to The 52nd Precinct!' featuring four photographs of police officers from the 52nd Precinct interacting with community members, particularly children, at what appears to be community events. The bottom of the page identifies the officers: Inspector Jeremy, Officer Gonzales, Myisha Hamilton (mother), Officer Easter, Officer DeLeon, Officer Gonzales, and Officer Boland. The page number 250 appears at the bottom.

A page featuring three photographs of Officer Arias with a young girl named Amari Austin and other officers. The text describes Amari's admiration for police officers and expresses gratitude from her family (grandmother Debra Hamilton and mother Myisha Hamilton) for Officer Arias's kindness and positive role in the child's life.

The Podcast with Ed Lover, The Joe Budden Podcast, and Million Dollaz Worth of Game with Gillie and Wallo. Title page for a hip-hop time capsule activity featuring 'Anita - Sharin' the Love'. The main content is displayed on a pink burst shape with torn paper effect against a purple and blue splattered background. Page number 257 appears at the bottom.

Biography page for DJ Cool Kev featuring a portrait photo and two paragraphs describing his career history, influences, education, collaborations, and extensive mixtape collection. The page includes a thank you message to supporters at the bottom.

Contact and marketing page for DJ Cool Kev featuring email contact information (coolkev117@aol.com), the Total Package Collection brand logo showing various mascot characters, two promotional photos of a man with children wearing branded apparel, and four QR codes linking to Instagram, Website, a newly published article about Total Package Collection Brand, and the Total Package Brand main page.

Profile page for Mark Borino, a music producer and songwriter. Features a centered portrait photo with QR codes for Instagram and ffm.bio on either side. Below is biographical text describing his work on Drake's 'Certified Lover Boy' album, particularly the track 'Papi's Home' which peaked at #8 on Billboard's Hot 100. Text mentions his Harold Adamson Lyric Award from ASCAP, his independent releases under 'House of Rivero' label, and recent songs 'Don't Wait Up' and 'Visions'. The page includes a personal recommendation from Anita at the bottom.

Profile page for Jamie Lynn featuring her photo, information about her 21-year career in NYC radio as an executive morning show producer, and her dog treat business 'Bark Avenue Treats'. Includes two QR codes for social media contact (@barkavenuetreats and Instagram) and a note from Anita encouraging readers to reach out to Jamie Lynn for her products.

A testimonial page about 'Donnell Land' featuring two photos of Donnell Rawlings with a woman (likely Anita), a description of the Memorial Day weekend experience at Donnell Land in Yellow Springs, Ohio, and two QR codes at the bottom - one for Donnell Land registration and one for Instagram (@donnellrawlings). The page includes a personal message signed by Anita.

A testimonial page honoring Adrian Silvestre, Director of Food and Beverage at City Experiences. The page features VIP laurel wreath logos at the top, a detailed acknowledgment of Adrian's career and contributions, mentions of cruises including the New York Bateaux, and includes QR codes and the City Experiences logo at the bottom. The page emphasizes Adrian's hospitality and the VIP experience he provides.

A page featuring Shaw-nae's House, a soul-food catering business. The page includes the restaurant logo at the top, three photos showing the chef with food and various dishes, a narrative text about how Shaw-nae connected with The Breakfast Club through a personal call, and five QR codes at the bottom linking to media mentions including New York Times, Elvis Duran, NYC Tourism, Today Show, and NYT's 50 Best Restaurants in America.
A blank page with only the page number 265 in the bottom right corner

A decorative page featuring 'Hip-Hop Time Capsule' branding with DJ Scipio's 'Thank-You' track title. The page has a purple and pink color scheme with a starburst design in the center. It includes the tagline 'Document Your Personal Journey' and shows page number 266.

A dedication page featuring two entries: one for Shirley Williams with purple floral decoration and a heartfelt thank you message, and another for Greg Simpkins with a photograph of two men shaking hands and a message thanking him for 46 years of friendship and support. Page number 267 appears at the bottom.

A title page with 'Hip-Hop Time Capsule' at the top, subtitle 'Document Your Personal Journey', and centered text reading 'DJ SCIPIO "SHOUT-OUTS"' on a pink burst/splash design against a purple background with page number 268 at bottom.

A 'DJ SHOUT-OUT' acknowledgments page thanking family members, especially sister Anita, and the Hip-Hop community including DJs, MCs, producers, and labels. The page features decorative elements including a purple brush stroke banner with 'SHOUT-OUT' text at the top, stylized 'DJ DUMP' text, and three music-related icons (record, DJ headphones, vinyl) at the bottom. Page number 269.

Acknowledgments page thanking fans and supporters. Features a 'Shout-out to the Carolinas' section with South Carolina and North Carolina state flags. Thanks The Breakfast Club/Power 105.1 radio station and names several individuals including Jess Hilarious, Loren LaRosa, and others. Includes 'Thank You' message from DJ SCIPIO and shout-out to Mikey Truth labeled as South Carolina's #1 Urban Blogger and Queen of Paperwork. Page includes decorative crown logo at bottom.

Shout-out/acknowledgments page featuring a decorative header with 'DJ SCIPIO' and 'SHOUT-OUT' text, followed by dedications to family members and a lengthy list of friends, colleagues, and associates in the music industry

A 'DJ NOTIQ SHOUT-OUT' acknowledgments page listing numerous DJs, radio personalities, artists, and industry professionals including DJ Cannon Banyon, Servin' Mike Ervin, DJ Dirty Baby, Derek White and Family, Crazy Obilla, and many others. The page features a purple brushstroke header design with white text.

A 'DJ SOHO SHOUT-OUT' page listing numerous hip-hop artists, DJs, producers, and music industry figures including Natalac, DJ Lord Jazz, Coke La Rock, Karate Pete Williams, and many others. The page appears to be acknowledgments or dedications from a book about hip-hop culture or history. Page number 273 appears at the bottom.

An 'About the Author' page featuring a photo of DJ SCIPIO (Hilton V. Scipio) at his DJ equipment wearing a red vest and white shirt with headphones. The text provides biographical information about DJ SCIPIO, describing his upbringing in Harlem, N.Y., his musical influences including Marvin Gaye, The Stylistics, The Manhattans, and The Delfonics, his family's move to The Bronx in 1973, and his early experiences with Hip-Hop music including songs like 'Apache' by Incredible Bongo Band, 'Mardi Gra' by Bob James, and 'Catch A'.

Biography page about DJ SCIPIO describing his early influences in New York City, including DJs like Kool Herc, GrandMaster Flash, and Grand Wizard Theodore, as well as his friend DJ Jazzy G and brother DJ KFD. The text details his move to Orangeburg, South Carolina in 1989 where he became influential in bringing Dirty South music to the region, earning over twenty awards including five consecutive Mixtape DJ of the Year awards in South Carolina.

An 'About the Author' page featuring a photograph and biography of Anita Scipio, former receptionist for iHeartMedia in New York. The page describes her nearly two-decade tenure at the company and her significance as 'Miss Anita' or 'Mama' to those who worked there. The text explains how she became an iconic figure and 'the face and soul of iHeartMedia,' witnessing the entertainment industry's evolution and meeting many celebrities.

A biographical tribute page about Anita Scipio describing her role at iHeartMedia's New York office, her nurturing of talent, her warm personality, and her impact as a mentor and community figure. The page highlights her legacy beyond administrative duties, including her work as an ordained minister and her charitable endeavors.

A page showcasing media interviews with two main sections. The top section features 'The Breakfast Club Interview' with a QR code and photo of four people in a radio studio. The bottom section shows an 'Angela Yee Interview' from the 'Way Up with Angela Yee' show with a QR code and photo of two people in a radio studio holding a book. The page header reads 'Hip-Hop Time Capsule and...' with The Breakfast Club logo.

A tribute page showing photos of a woman with various hip-hop artists and celebrities including Kool Moe Dee, LL Cool J, Ice-T, DMX, Snoop Dogg, Rick Ross, 2 Chainz, Fat Joe, and Treach. The page is titled 'Thank you all, for the love and great memories...' and displays 9 photographs arranged in a 3x3 grid, each labeled with the celebrity's name.

A collage page showing a woman posing with various hip-hop and R&B celebrities including Mary J Blige, Kid 'n Play, Ice Cube, Redman, Meek Mill, Moneybagg Yo, Rev Run, DMC, and A$AP Rocky. Each photo is labeled with the celebrity's name beneath it. The page number 280 appears at the bottom.

A collage page showing Will Smith's viral moment visiting a receptionist named Anita Scipio at iHeartRadio for her retirement after 30 years. The page includes multiple screenshots from various media outlets (Instagram, Daily Mail, CNN, InspireMore, WLOS) covering the story from January 2020. The page is titled 'THEN LAST BUT NOT LEAST... WILL SMITH' with a subtitle 'AND MY (BARELY) 15 MINUTES OF FAME!' and includes a QR code. The layout shows various social media posts and news articles about the surprise visit.

A reflective page featuring two QR codes at the top (one labeled 'Will Smith' and one labeled 'Reflecting on My Viral Moment with Will Smith'), a central Instagram-style photo showing two people in conversation, and a handwritten-style text below signed by Anita. The text expresses gratitude for encounters with Hip-Hop celebrities and mentions creating a 'Hip-Hop Time Capsule: The Next Chapter' to share detailed stories about each pictured celebrity.

A scrapbook-style page documenting a retirement party, featuring multiple photos, QR codes, and text snippets. Includes images from Elvis Duran's radio show appearance, a birthday party invitation for 'Hala', a 'Mama's VIP' sign, party decorations, and celebration photos. Text elements highlight favorite songs ('Suge' by DaBaby, 'It Takes Two' by Rob Base, 'Lean On Me' by Bill Withers), shout-outs to DJs, and mentions of gifts including a trip to Paris, Nashville and $10,000. Multiple QR codes are placed throughout with labels like '*Ugly Cry Alert', '*Favorite Dance Song of The Night', '*Classic Song of the night', and '*Song I want to be remembered by'. The page appears to be page 285 of a memory book or retirement album.

Final page titled 'Heartfelt Wishes' containing closing remarks and inspirational message from the authors. The page thanks readers for their participation, shares the authors' journey to publication including obstacles faced, mentions appearances on the Breakfast Club and Angela Yee's show, and concludes with advice to 'BE Fearless' as DJ Envy would say. Page number 286.

A thank you page from authors Anita and Hilton requesting readers to leave reviews on Amazon. The page includes a photo of the couple, 'Love and Blessings' header text, and four QR codes linking to: Amazon Reviews, Anita's Instagram, Team Scipio Website, and DJ Scipio's Logo. Page number 287 appears at the bottom.
